subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS-SAMPA: a proposed format for plain-text Quickscript
msgSnippet: ... Thanks. I m glad you find my proposal worthwhile. ... And rightly so. Normal QS typography should definitely be Junior ; ligatures are really typographic
messageBody:
Ted Larson Freeman skrev:
> Hi Benct,
>
> This is a good proposal. (And no, you're not too late to
> influence the development of a standard for Senior QS!)

Thanks. I'm glad you find my proposal worthwhile.

> My primary interest is in establishing a good standard
> notation for Junior QS,

And rightly so. Normal QS typography should definitely be
'Junior'; ligatures are really 'typographic sugar' and while
half-letters are intended to speed up handwriting, but just
as I don't expect the four combinatory variants of s I use
in my handwriting to be reflected in typography I wouldn't
expect every aspect of handwritten QS to be reflected in
every piece of typographic QS. Since we however may be
expected to discuss the pros and cons of different
handwritten spellings it is a good thing to have ligatures
and half-letters available in the font, but they should IMO
not be regarded as required for correct typing or spelling.

> and I'll admit that my suggestions for ligatures was quite
> random, and that I completely ignored half-letters. Your
> ideas here are solid. All of these letters can be easily
> typed using the US Extended keyboard.

Looking at the US-International keyboard I see this is the
case, which is Good! :-)

<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keyboard_layout#US-International>

It must be somewhat irritating to have to press the space
bar to get a normal apostrophe! I find the constant
AltGR+"+Spacebar to get ~ on my Swedish keyboard, when
writing Perl code quite tedious!


> Regarding your suggestion to assign 'q' to #21: some of
> the assignments in X-SAMPA may not be to our liking, but
> I'd like to follow them wherever practical. Also, 'N' is
> the current mapping in existing QS fonts.
>
> As to assigning 'ñ' to the alternate letter for #23, a
> design goal for QS-SAMPA is to stick to 7-bit ASCII for
> all 44 letters, 2 alternates, and 3 punctuation marks. The
> alternate for #23 is used so frequently that it needs to
> be easy to type. On a US Keyboard 'ñ' is typed with 'Alt-
> n n', taking three key strokes, while 'q' uses, well, one.
> I'd prefer to stick to 'q', which I think will become
> habitual almost immediately.

I've actually found that q has a vague visual similarity to
the QS character in question (circle with protruding lines
at the bottom). Besides I won't be using it in normal typing
very often, given my preference for Junior spellings in
typography.!

Paul, if you are reading this, would you be willing to
incorporate my suggestions in your font? Or make a version
incorporating them? I was thinking of trying to make a font,
but I'd rather put my energy on my 'At-Ox-dictionary' at
this time.

/BP 8^)>
--
